text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Norwegian papers this morning:

- Some 80 percent of fathers now use their right to a four-week paternity leave. Only four percent took such a leave in 1993. Family Minister Grete Berget says the increase is fantastic and proves that the government's policy of making fathers assume more responsibility at home is working.
-Rimi supermarket chain open on Sundays despite protests by union.

- British Petroleum Norway will pay tax for the first time in 1997, after working on the Norwegian continental shelf for 20 years. High oil prices give BP Norway a taxable income on several hundred million crowns this year.
- Norway's largest newspaper Verdens Gang (VG) has stabilised it's circulation after slipping for 18 months. The circulation in August was 367,389 copies.

- A strong growth in Internet users has prompted state-owned telecompany Telenor's division Telenor Online to invest 150 million crowns in technology to improve capacity and the quality of Internet access. Telenor expects to have 150,000-200,000 Internet customers next year.
